thread.title: The Wall Street Journal: Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu questioned in third corruption investigation

title: The Wall Street Journal: Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu questioned in third corruption investigation
text:
Published: Mar 2, 2018 10:20 a.m. ET Share 
Probe alleges officials promoted certain regulation in return for positive media coverage Reuters U.S. President Donald Trump and Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu meet in Jerusalem last May. 
By Rory Jones 
Israeli police Friday questioned Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu as a suspect in a third corruption investigation that poses a serious challenge to the embattled leader, who so far has rallied support to maintain power. 
Police also questioned the prime minister’s wife Sara Netanyahu regarding the case, conducting the interview at the same time as her husband but in a different location, a police spokeswoman said. The police haven’t yet ascertained whether the first lady is also a suspect, the spokeswomen said. Netanyahu was questioned at home Friday. 
The investigation focuses on whether Israeli officials organized positive media coverage for Mr. Netanyahu and his wife on a popular news website. In return, police say officials promoted regulation worth tens of millions of dollars to the site’s owner, telecom firm Bezeq and one of its major shareholders. 
Police already have recommended corruption charges against Mr. Netanyahu in two other cases, but this investigation—known as Case 4000—is considered more serious by many observers because it involves larger sums of money and the country’s biggest listed telecom firm. The former director of the communications ministry and confidant of Mr. Netanyahu, Shlomo Filber, also turned state witness in the case last week.
